section.title: Yield Rates and Reinvestment Rates
section.p: The yield rate on an investment is the rate of return (treated mathematically as an interest rate) that relates the present and future values of an investment. If L is the present value and M is the future value after n periods, the effective periodic yield rate \iota satisfies:
If instead of a present value, you have, say, an annuity with level payments K, then the yield rate satisfies:
In this case, these amounts are actually received by the investor (or contributed by the investor).

In contrast, the internal rate of return is the rate used to value cash streams, whether or not that is actually realized by the investor. For example, when a loan involves level payments based on an interest rate of \iota, we have
The interest rate is the internal rate of return. This is the interest rate in the loan agreement, and defines how the payments are valued.
If payments received by an investor are reinvested (in a savings account or a sinking fund, for example), the rate earned on the reinvestment account is, simply enough, the reinvestment rate.
The internal rate of return is defined for the given cash flows (more on that later in this chapter). The reinvestment rate determines the yield rate.

introduction.p: Let's look at this with an example. Suppose we have a 10-year loan of 10,000. The borrower is charged an interest rate of 5%. For each of the following repayment and reinvestment options, find (i) the internal rate of return, (ii) the reinvestment rate, and (iii) the yield rate.

task.p: The loan is paid off with annual level payments. Payments are reinvested at 5%.
The loan is paid off with annual payments of interest, with the principal paid back with the final interest payment. Payments are reinvested at 5%.
The loan is paid off with a single payment (accumulated interest plus principal) at the end of the term.

section.p: There is another, related way, to value an annuity such as a loan. If an investor pays P for a series of n level payments of K, they can obtain a yield rate \iota with each payment while recovering principal in a sinking fund with interest rate j. They do so by taking \iota P out of each payment for their own consumption, and depositing the rest in the sinking fund. In this case, \iota is the yield rate and j is the reinvestment rate (while the internal rate of return still equates P with the present values of the payments K).

statement.p: Suppose a loan has ten annual payments of 1,000 and immediately sold to an investor. The investor pays a price P which allows him to yield 4% and recover their principal investment in a sinking fund bearing an effective annual interest rate of j = 0.05. How much should they pay for the loan?

Do you need a formula for the price to pay for such an investment? If you want one, derive one. If you do not, explain how you will solve problems involving recovery of principal through sinking funds.

introduction.p: An investor makes a single deposit of 10,000 into Fund A for 10 years which earns a 6% effective rate of interest payable directly to the investor each year. During the first 5 years, the interest payments can only be reinvested into Fund B which earns 4% effective over the entire 10-year period. During the second 5 years, the interest payment can only be invested in Fund C which earns 5% effective.

task.p: Find the total accumulated value in Funds A, B, and C combined at the end of 10 years. Answer to the nearest dollar.
Find the overall yield rate achieved by the investor.
